title: Spectra - number of frequencies emitted by X Y Z

content.question: Three hypothetical atoms, <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Z</mtext></math>, have energy levels as shown in the diagram, where the energies are given in terms of a constant <math alttext="E sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The atoms get excited so that all energy levels are occupied, and each atom then emits light with a spectrum of frequencies corresponding to all of the transitions between the energy levels depicted in the diagram. Which of the following correctly ranks the number <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi></math> of distinct frequencies in the emission spectra of atoms <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Z</mtext></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="n sub X is greater than, n sub Y, which equals n sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="n sub X equals, n sub Z, which is greater than n sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="n sub Y is greater than, n sub X, which equals n sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="n sub Y equals, n sub Z, which is greater than n sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="n sub Y equals, n sub Z, which is greater than n sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>
